Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Take and record vital signs like temperature, pulse, and blood pressure
Situation2: The nursing assistant is on their morning rounds to take a patient's routine vital signs.
Story: I glance at my phone, seeing the text from my boyfriend: “Can’t wait for tonight. Just us.” It’s the only evening we have together before I leave for a week, and he’s been looking forward to it for days. I promised him I’d be home early, that I’d leave work on time for once. But as I move down the hospital hallway, clipboard in hand, I hear the charge nurse call my name. “We’re short-staffed. Can you cover the next round of vitals?” My heart sinks. I know what’s expected of me here—every patient needs their temperature, pulse, and blood pressure checked, and the team is counting on me. But I also know what tonight means to him, and to us. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in, my chest tight with guilt and frustration. I want to be the reliable girlfriend he needs, but I can’t ignore the patients who depend on me. I stand frozen in the hallway, torn between the promise I made at home and the duty I have here, wishing I could be in two places at once.
